Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:EAPSI: Integrating English and Chinese-Language Literature on the India-Asia Collision to Better Understand the Formation and Evolution of Subduction Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Before India and Asia collided, forming the Himalayas, the oceanic plate between the continents was subducted beneath Asia. The material scraped off from the oceanic plate during subduction, called a subduction complex, is one of the few records of the material that entered the subduction zone. Most of the material is subducted into the mantle and lost to the geologic record. Integrating data from Chinese-language and English-language sources will provide a holistic understanding of the subduction complex in southern Tibet. This project will analyze and compile maps and data available only in China with those from English-language publications and new data generated in the United States and China. This research will be conducted at the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research in collaboration with Professor Ding Lin and his students, who have worked extensively on the subduction complex in southern Tibet. The collaboration could lead to the discovery of new continental fragments that were subducted and a new model for how subduction complexes develop.

This project will integrate the extent, deformation style, and provenance of the subduction complex in southern Tibet. Primary data will be maps, unit descriptions, U-Pb detrital zircon geochronology, and sedimentary provenance. The subduction complex in southern Tibet is a complicated, little-studied unit that records the source and deformation of materials entering the subduction zone and that is composed almost entirely of block-in-matrix m√©lange, far thicker and more mixed than any other documented subduction complex. This block-in-matrix style of deformation over kilometers width in a few millions of years is unexplained by current subduction zone models.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of China.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In subduction zones, material is scraped off the subducting plate and accreted to the upper plate, forming a subduction complex. Subduction complexes are difficult to study because active complexes are usually submerged and poorly imaged while ancient complexes exposed on land are often overprinted by later deformation. The subduction complex is one of the only records of material that entered the trench over time. India and Asia collided along what was once a subduction zone. Understanding how the subduction complex in southern Tibet formed, deformed, and was exhumed has implications for how active and ancient subduction complexes around the world develop.

 

Because of the language and access barriers, it is difficult for westerners to study maps and papers published in Chinese. While most high-impact papers are now published in English, older papers and those with data but of modest scientific impact are commonly published in Chinese. There are many ways that the rocks in the India-Asia collision zone are named and divided, causing great confusion and incorrect correlations in the literature. In a previous field season, I documented geologic formation which has not been described in western literature. The purpose of this project was to compile and correlate all the known unit classifications, search for evidence of the formation I documented in the Chinese literature, and form professional relationships with researchers in China to conduct future joint projects in Tibet.

 

This project resulted in an ongoing, international collaboration with Chinese scholars at the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. With the help of my colleagues, I studied and translated maps available only in China as well as Chinese studies to include in a review of the geology of the region. With data from multiple bodies of literature, we are developing a guide to help other researchers compare rocks across different classification schemes. My Chinese colleagues and I agree that the geologic formation that I documented has not been identified in either the western or Chinese literature. Both I and my Chinese hosts benefitted from the exchange of ideas and look forward to working together again on a future field project.
